0.html:
The mantra-py lib provides 4 main modules:

  • Wallet, to create addresses and send transactions.
  • Client, to query blockchain information.
  • TxBuilder, to interact with the blockchain.
  • Webhooks, to subscribe to on-chain events.
  • Constants, to get the chain configuration values.

Examples

  • Webhooks API, using the Webhooks module, it provides an API to subscribe to events from outside your program.
0.text:
The mantra-py lib provides 4 main modules:

Wallet, to create addresses and send transactions.
Client, to query blockchain information.
TxBuilder, to interact with the blockchain.
Webhooks, to subscribe to on-chain events.
Constants, to get the chain configuration values.

Examples

Webhooks API, using the Webhooks module, it provides an API to subscribe to events from outside your program.
0.title: Get started

1.html:
Mantrapy includes a client to interact with the Mantra network via:

  • API: to execute queries or transaction against the application.
  • RPC: to execute queries or transactions against Comet BFT.
1.text:
Mantrapy includes a client to interact with the Mantra network via:

API: to execute queries or transaction against the application.
RPC: to execute queries or transactions against Comet BFT.
1.title: Client

3.html:
client = Client(api_endpoint, rpc_endpoint, timeout, max_retries)

Where it possible to specify API and RPC endpoints for testnet or mainnet, the timeout of each request, and the number of retries if a request fails.
3.text:
client = Client(api_endpoint, rpc_endpoint, timeout, max_retries)
Where it possible to specify API and RPC endpoints for testnet or mainnet, the
timeout of each request, and the number of retries if a request fails.
3.title: Instantiate the client

4.html: All queries performed via the mantrapy client return a QueryResponse type which wrap the returned data, the response status, and the possible error.
4.text:
All queries performed via the mantrapy client return a QueryResponse type
which wrap the returned data, the response status, and the possible error.
4.title: Query

5.html:
It is possible to query the account information associated with an address:

get_account(address: str) -> QueryResponse[QueryAccountResponse]:
5.text:
It is possible to query the account information associated with an address:
get_account(address: str) -> QueryResponse[QueryAccountResponse]:
5.title: Account

6.html:
It is possible to get all balances of an account via:

get_balances(address: str) -> QueryResponse[QueryBalancesResponse]:

get_balances(address: str) -> QueryResponse[QueryBalancesResponse]:

get_delegator_delegations(address: str) -> QueryResponse[QueryDelegatorDelegationsResponse]:

It is possible to retrieve the last block height:

get_height() -> QueryResponse[str]:

11.html:
It is possible to retrieve a block's information using the height:

get_block_by_height(height: int) -> QueryResponse[ResultBlock]:

Or via its hash:

get_block_by_hash(hash: str) -> QueryResponse[ResultBlock]:

It is possible to retrieve a block's information using the height:
get_block_by_height(height: int) -> QueryResponse[ResultBlock]:
Or via its hash:

12.html:
It is possible to query a transaction given its hash value:

get_tx_by_hash(hash: str) -> QueryResponse[ResultTx]:

12.title: Trasnsaction

14.html:
The mantrapy client can be used to broadcast any signed transaction via:

broadcast(tx) -> str:

Please, refer to the transaction builder documentation to understand how to create a signed transaction.
14.text:
The mantrapy client can be used to broadcast any signed transaction via:
broadcast(tx) -> str:
Please, refer to the transaction builder documentation to understand how to
create a signed transaction.
14.title: Broadcasting a transaction

16.html:
To execute a query, you first have to instantiate the Client as described in the previous section, and then call the method you want to execute as in the example below:

from mantrapy.client.client import Client
from mantrapy.constants.constants import Constants
 
constants = Constants()
client = Client(constants.api_endpoint, constants.rpc_endpoint)
block_resp = client.get_block_by_height(1)
# Status of the request
print(block_resp.status_code)
# Content of the request
print(block_resp.data)

Where the Constant class contains the endpoints for both mainnet and testnet.

You can find more query examples in the ./examples/queries/ folder.
16.text:
To execute a query, you first have to instantiate the Client as described in the
previous section, and then call the method you want to execute as in the example
below:
from mantrapy.client.client import Client
from mantrapy.constants.constants import Constants
 
constants = Constants()
client = Client(constants.api_endpoint, constants.rpc_endpoint)
block_resp = client.get_block_by_height(1)
# Status of the request
print(block_resp.status_code)
# Content of the request
print(block_resp.data)
Where the Constant class contains the endpoints for both mainnet and testnet.
You can find more query examples in the ./examples/queries/ folder.
16.title: Execute a query

17.html: The constants pkg is used to read from the environment variable the chain values.
17.text: The constants pkg is used to read from the environment variable the chain values.
17.title: Constants

18.html:
• 'API_ENDPOINT'
  • 'RPC_ENDPOINT'
  • 'CHAIN_ID'
  • 'DENOM', the denomination is used to pay the network fees.
18.title: Env Vars

19.html:
If the env vars are not set, the constants object will default to Mantra Mainnet.

Calling the constants.testnet() function will overwrite the values with the Testnet configuration.
19.text:
If the env vars are not set, the constants object will default to Mantra Mainnet.
Calling the constants.testnet() function will overwrite the values with the Testnet configuration.
19.title: Default Values

20.html:
from mantrapy.constants.constants import Constants
 
c = Constants()
c.testnet()
print(c.api_endpoint)
print(c.rpc)
20.text:
from mantrapy.constants.constants import Constants
 
c = Constants()
c.testnet()
print(c.api_endpoint)
print(c.rpc)
20.title: Usage

21.html:
The TxBuilder package allows the user to crate and sign cosmos transactions.

The TxBuilder class accepts an option argument to set the network, by default it will use Mainnet.

The builder assumes that you want to sign the message with your local wallet (builder.sign_message).

If you want to sign the message with an external wallet, you need to create a Wallet object with the private key and then use your external wallet to sign the sign_doc.
21.text:
The TxBuilder package allows the user to crate and sign cosmos transactions.
The TxBuilder class accepts an option argument to set the network, by default it will use Mainnet.
The builder assumes that you want to sign the message with your local wallet (builder.sign_message).
If you want to sign the message with an external wallet, you need to create a Wallet object with the private key and then use your external wallet to sign the sign_doc.
21.title: Transaction Builder

22.html:
from mantrapy.txbuilder.builder import TxBuilder
from mantrapy.wallet.wallet import wallet_from_mnemonic
 
TEST_MNEMONIC = 'anger pencil awful note doctor like slide muffin hungry keen appear eight barrel stone quiz candy loud blush load three analyst buddy health member'  # noqa: E501
w = wallet_from_mnemonic(TEST_MNEMONIC)
 
builder = TxBuilder(w, is_testnet=True)
body, auth, sign_doc = builder.bank_send('mantra1wf2eqtltm35tc5dllhp9uuzy66qvuwhve7zzgr', 1, 'uom')
resp = builder.broadcast_tx(body, auth, builder.sign_message(sign_doc))
22.text:
from mantrapy.txbuilder.builder import TxBuilder
from mantrapy.wallet.wallet import wallet_from_mnemonic
 
TEST_MNEMONIC = 'anger pencil awful note doctor like slide muffin hungry keen appear eight barrel stone quiz candy loud blush load three analyst buddy health member'  # noqa: E501
w = wallet_from_mnemonic(TEST_MNEMONIC)
 
builder = TxBuilder(w, is_testnet=True)
body, auth, sign_doc = builder.bank_send('mantra1wf2eqtltm35tc5dllhp9uuzy66qvuwhve7zzgr', 1, 'uom')
resp = builder.broadcast_tx(body, auth, builder.sign_message(sign_doc))
22.title: Message Send Example

23.html:
To generate the transaction, several internal functions are needed.

If you want to use some custom configuration you can use the mantrapy.txbuilder.transactions pkg.
23.text:

from mantrapy.wallet.wallet import wallet_from_mnemonic
 
TEST_MNEMONIC = 'anger pencil awful note doctor like slide muffin hungry keen appear eight barrel stone quiz candy loud blush load three analyst buddy health member'  # noqa: E501

28.title: Getters

29.html: The mantrapy library provides tools for integrating webhooks into your application. This module is split into three main components: ChainClient, EventProcessor, and a Webhook class, which work together to facilitate real-time processing and handling of blockchain events through webhooks.
29.text: The mantrapy library provides tools for integrating webhooks into your application. This module is split into three main components: ChainClient, EventProcessor, and a Webhook class, which work together to facilitate real-time processing and handling of blockchain events through webhooks.
29.title: Mantrapy Webhooks Documentation

31.html: ChainClient manages WebSocket connections and subscriptions to blockchain event streams. This client is used to connect to CometBFT (prev. Tendermint) RPC.
31.text: ChainClient manages WebSocket connections and subscriptions to blockchain event streams. This client is used to connect to CometBFT (prev. Tendermint) RPC.
31.title: ChainClient

32.html:
• Parameters:
    • websocket_url (str): The WebSocket URL for the blockchain server.
32.text:
Parameters:

websocket_url (str): The WebSocket URL for the blockchain server.
32.title: Class: ChainClient

33.html:
• connect(): Establishes a connection to the WebSocket server.

    • Returns: None
    • Raises: InvalidURI, InvalidHandshake

  • subscribe(query, max_retries=3): Subscribes to a specified query and yields incoming messages.

    • Parameters:
      • query (str): The query string to subscribe to. For example, to get all events when there's a transaction, use "tm.event='Tx'". For more information about events subscription on CometBFT and Cosmos-SDK chains, refer to their docs.
      • max_retries (int): Maximum number of reconnection attempts.
    • Returns: Async generator yielding WebSocket messages.
    • Raises: ConnectionClosedError, InvalidStatusCode, TimeoutError
33.text:
connect(): Establishes a connection to the WebSocket server.

Returns: None
Raises: InvalidURI, InvalidHandshake



subscribe(query, max_retries=3): Subscribes to a specified query and yields incoming messages.

Parameters:

query (str): The query string to subscribe to. For example, to get all events when there's a transaction, use "tm.event='Tx'". For more information about events subscription on CometBFT and Cosmos-SDK chains, refer to their docs.
max_retries (int): Maximum number of reconnection attempts.


Returns: Async generator yielding WebSocket messages.
Raises: ConnectionClosedError, InvalidStatusCode, TimeoutError
33.title: Methods

34.html:
from mantrapy.webhooks.chain_client import ChainClient
import asyncio
 
async def main():
    client = ChainClient("wss://example.com/socket")
    await client.connect()
    async for message in client.subscribe("tm.event='Tx'"):
        print("Received event:", message)
 
asyncio.run(main())
34.text:
from mantrapy.webhooks.chain_client import ChainClient
import asyncio
 
async def main():
    client = ChainClient("wss://example.com/socket")
    await client.connect()
    async for message in client.subscribe("tm.event='Tx'"):
        print("Received event:", message)
 
asyncio.run(main())
34.title: Example

35.html: EventProcessor processes and sends events via a POST HTTP request to a specified webhook endpoint. It allows for retries and exponential backoff in case of network issues.
35.text: EventProcessor processes and sends events via a POST HTTP request to a specified webhook endpoint. It allows for retries and exponential backoff in case of network issues.
35.title: EventProcessor

36.html:
• Parameters:
    • webhook_url (str): The URL of the webhook.
    • process_event_fn (callable): A function to process raw events (filtering/formatting).
    • post_retries (int): Number of retry attempts for failed webhook posts.
36.text:
Parameters:

webhook_url (str): The URL of the webhook.
process_event_fn (callable): A function to process raw events (filtering/formatting).
post_retries (int): Number of retry attempts for failed webhook posts.
36.title: Class: EventProcessor

37.html:
• set_query(query): Sets a query field in the notifications posted to the webhook url.
    • Parameters:
      • query (str): The event query string.
  • set_hook_id(hook_id): Sets a unique hook identifier that is included in the notifications posted to the webhook url.
    • Parameters:
      • hook_id (str): Identifier for the hook.
  • process_events(events): Processes events and sends the result via a POST HTTP request to the webhook URL. The results are sent in the body of the request as a JSON object with fields events (list), hook_id (str - optional) and query (str - optional).
    • Parameters:
      • events (list): List of events to process.
    • Raises: requests.exceptions.RequestException
37.text:
set_query(query): Sets a query field in the notifications posted to the webhook url.

Parameters:

query (str): The event query string.




set_hook_id(hook_id): Sets a unique hook identifier that is included in the notifications posted to the webhook url.

Parameters:

hook_id (str): Identifier for the hook.




process_events(events): Processes events and sends the result via a POST HTTP request to the webhook URL.
The results are sent in the body of the request as a JSON object with fields events (list), hook_id (str - optional) and query (str - optional).


Parameters:

events (list): List of events to process.


Raises: requests.exceptions.RequestException
37.title: Methods

38.html:
from mantrapy.webhooks.event_processor import EventProcessor
 
def process_event_fn(events):
    # Custom processing logic for events
    return [{"type": event["type"], "data": event["attributes"]} for event in events]
 
processor = EventProcessor("https://webhook.example.com", process_event_fn)
processor.set_hook_id("hook_123")
processor.set_query("my-custom-query")
 
# Process a batch of events
# Usually this comes from the subscription of a ChainClient
events = [{'type': 'message', 'attributes': [{'key': 'action', 'value': '/cosmos.bank.v1beta1.MsgSend', 'index': True}, {'key': 'sender', 'value': 'mantra1nagtgts4y4s3d08ykqe0vsd68l53gnlujms9zj', 'index': True}, {'key': 'module', 'value': 'bank', 'index': True}, {'key': 'msg_index', 'value': '0', 'index': True}]}]
processor.process_events(events)

In this example, the webhook will send a POST request to the https://webhook.example.com URL with the following body:

{
  "events": [
    {
      "type": "message",
      "data": [
        {
          "key": "action",
          "value": "/cosmos.bank.v1beta1.MsgSend",
          "index": true
        },
        {
          "key": "sender",
          "value": "mantra1nagtgts4y4s3d08ykqe0vsd68l53gnlujms9zj",
          "index": true
        },
        { "key": "module", "value": "bank", "index": true },
        { "key": "msg_index", "value": "0", "index": true }
      ]
    }
  ],
  "query": "my-custom-query",
  "hook_id": "hook_123"
}

Note that the resulting events array was processed by the process_event_fn and changed the original attributes field for a data field.
38.title: Example

39.html: The Webhook class brings together ChainClient and EventProcessor to handle WebSocket subscriptions and send events to a specified webhook URL.
39.text: The Webhook class brings together ChainClient and EventProcessor to handle WebSocket subscriptions and send events to a specified webhook URL.
39.title: Webhook

40.html:
• Parameters:
    • websocket_url (str): WebSocket URL for blockchain connections.
    • webhook_url (str): URL for sending processed events.
    • process_fn (callable): A function for processing WebSocket events.
    • event_query (str): Query for the events to subscribe to on the CometBFT (prev. Tendermint) RPC. Defaults to "tm.event='Tx'". For more information, refer to their docs.
  • Methods
    • listen(): Listens for incoming events and processes them before forwarding to the webhook URL.
      • Returns: None
      • Raises: JSONDecodeError, KeyError
40.text:
Parameters:

websocket_url (str): WebSocket URL for blockchain connections.
webhook_url (str): URL for sending processed events.
process_fn (callable): A function for processing WebSocket events.
event_query (str): Query for the events to subscribe to on the CometBFT (prev. Tendermint) RPC. Defaults to "tm.event='Tx'". For more information, refer to their docs.



Methods

listen(): Listens for incoming events and processes them before forwarding to the webhook URL.

Returns: None
Raises: JSONDecodeError, KeyError
40.title: Class: Webhook

41.html:
from mantrapy.webhooks.webhook import Webhook
 
# Define a custom event processing function
def process_event(events):
    return [{"event_type": event["type"], "content": event["attributes"]} for event in events]
 
webhook = Webhook("wss://blockchain.example.com/socket", "https://webhook.example.com", process_event)
 
# Start listening for events
import asyncio
asyncio.run(webhook.listen())
41.text:
from mantrapy.webhooks.webhook import Webhook
 
# Define a custom event processing function
def process_event(events):
    return [{"event_type": event["type"], "content": event["attributes"]} for event in events]
 
webhook = Webhook("wss://blockchain.example.com/socket", "https://webhook.example.com", process_event)
 
# Start listening for events
import asyncio
asyncio.run(webhook.listen())
41.title: Example

42.html:
A specialized webhook for handling smart contract events, SmartContractWebhook uses the Webhook base class and custom event-processing logic.

from mantrapy.webhooks.hooks.webhook import Webhook
from mantrapy.webhooks.modules.smart_contract import get_smart_contracts_events
 
class SmartContractWebhook(Webhook):
    def __init__(self, websocket_url, webhook_url):
        super().__init__(websocket_url, webhook_url, get_smart_contracts_events)
 
# Usage
smart_contract_webhook = SmartContractWebhook("wss://smartchain.example.com/socket", "https://webhook.example.com")
asyncio.run(smart_contract_webhook.listen())
42.text:
A specialized webhook for handling smart contract events, SmartContractWebhook uses the Webhook base class and custom event-processing logic.
from mantrapy.webhooks.hooks.webhook import Webhook
from mantrapy.webhooks.modules.smart_contract import get_smart_contracts_events
 
class SmartContractWebhook(Webhook):
    def __init__(self, websocket_url, webhook_url):
        super().__init__(websocket_url, webhook_url, get_smart_contracts_events)
 
# Usage
smart_contract_webhook = SmartContractWebhook("wss://smartchain.example.com/socket", "https://webhook.example.com")
asyncio.run(smart_contract_webhook.listen())
42.title: Example Usage: SmartContractWebhook
